 Technical Annex Page 1 A. BACKGROUND 1. The massive movements of population, and the concentration of people in those parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina (BH) considered safer than others, have resulted in major problems in the delivery of basic water, sanitation and solid waste services to the population. Water supplies in many urban centers are grossly inadequate for the number of people requiring services, leaving many people suffering from serious privation. Waterborne diseases are becoming increasingly common, water service is intermittent and water contamination from insufficiently treated wastewater remains a constant hazard. Furthermnore, arrangements for the disposal of solid waste have almost collapsed, bringing new health hazards to citizens. 2. Bosnia and Herzegovina (the State, comprising the Bosniac-Croat Federation and the Republic of Srpska) estimates the total sector requirements for restoration of service to prewar levels and upgrading to meet changed conditions at $950 million. Taking into consideration the implementation capacity of the existing institutions, the Bank has proposed a 3-year US$380 million program that would be implemented with three separately financed projects. The proposed Project would be the first one in the program. It comprises equipment supply, urgent works, strategic planning, institutional strengthening and preparation of the next project at an estimated cost of $70 million and would target needs in the Federation. The second and third projects would address needs in both the Federation and the Republic of Srpska. Sector Organization 3. Federal Level. The responsible Ministry is the Ministry of Agriculture, Water Resources and Forestry (MAWRF). The MAWRF sets policies and standards and recommends legislation for all water management functions. Implementation of the policy and legislation is the responsibility of Vodoprivreda BH (VBH). This is the organization that is responsible for the rehabilitation of the sector and would manage the proposed Project. VBH's headquarters are in Sarajevo. At present, there is only one regional office which is located in Mostar. VBH has plans to establish two more regional offices in Tuzla and Bihac. 4. Municipal Level. Municipalities have primary responsibility for the provision of water supply, sanitation and solid waste services in BH. They provide these services through komunalcos (municipal service companies) that function like municipally owned joint stock companies. Tariffs must be approved by the municipalities served, but finances are kept separate from municipal revenues. In the past project proposals for investments generally were initiated by the komunalcos. If the projects were local and did not require federal funding, they were planned and implemented by the komunalcos If they were regional, they were implemented by VBH. Sector Issues and Policies 5. Water Supply. The quality of water supply service in BH has deteriorated sharply since 1991. Whereas in the past, piped municipal water supply coverage in most urban areas was good (90% of population served) and 24 hour service was the norm, now in many areas service is intermittent and water quality has deteriorated. The main reasons for the deterioration of service have been: (i) increased demand from the influx of refugees; (ii) existing water sources having been made inaccessible as a result of the war; (iii) waste by consumers when water is available because meters are no longer read and bills are no longer collected; (iv) excessive water leakages in transmission and distribution networks as a result of lack of maintenance during the war; and (v) direct damage resulting from the war. The lack of maintenance, the primary cause of today's problems, resulted from constraints on labor and capital during
 Technical Annex Page 2 the hostilities as well as the widespread practice of charging very little for water, so that funds were generally not available for maintenance. Also, many technicians left, leaving water and sewerage works organizations undermanned. For example, the Sarajevo Water and Sewerage Works is currently operating with only one-third of their pre-war staff. While coverage in the pre-war period was good in urban areas, most rural areas still relied on dug wells or vender supplied water. Piped water supply coverage in rural areas is only 56% of the population. Thus, a timebound program to introduce water charges, taking into account peoples' capacity to pay, seems to be an essential precondition for any major investments beyond the initial "firefighting" effort. 6. Sewerage. Prior to 1991, BH had made significant progress in developing water borne sewage collection and treatment systems. Collection system coverage in urban areas averaged 70% as compared to 90% for water supply. Less than 10% of the rural population was connected to a water borne sewerage system. Most of the population relied on septic tanks which were satisfactory. Secondary treatment of wastewater in modern treatment plants was the exception. The largest and most important wastewater treatment plant is in Sarajevo, but few other towns have made investments beyond screening and grit removal. As is the case for water distribution, lack of maintenance has also been a problem. Leaky sewer systems with collectors dating back to 1920 create the potential for contamination of the water system and nearby aquifers. This lack of maintenance and in some places war damage have contributed to sewer pipe blockages, sewer pipe breaks, pumping station failures and treatment plant shutdowns. In Vitez, Novi Travnik and Gornji Vakuf, the sewerage systems are in such poor condition that reconstruction of the system is the only economic alternative. Geologically, the South-Western region of BH with its sensitive "karst" area relies heavily on the use of groundwater for water supply, calling for special efforts to avoid contamination of groundwater aquifers. Rivers used for water supply are also being polluted from untreated discharges of municipal and industrial wastewater, but this is not a new condition resulting from the war. Rivers most affected are the Sava, Bosnia, Litvia, Lasva and Vrbas. There is much to be done towards improving wastewater collection and treatment. In the proposed Project, priority would be given to the repair and rehabilitation of the collection systems. 7. Solid Waste. Prior to 1991, most municipalities had fairly well organized waste collection services, ensuring delivery of solid wastes to landfill sites or temporary disposal areas although few of the sites were properly designed. Service has collapsed in many urban areas because most garbage trucks were either destroyed or became inoperable during the war due to lack of maintenance and availability of spare parts. Municipalities that had joint disposal sites before the war, today in some cases, refuse to share facilities and many divided municipalities have lost access to garbage trucks and containers to handle their refuse. In many urban areas, restoration of dependable solid waste collection service is as critical as improving water supply services. Bank Pre-war Involvement in the Sector 8. The Bank made 28 loans to BH as a former Republic of Yugoslavia, two of which included water and sanitation components. They were: (i) Ln 1263 Sarajevo Water and Wastewater Project; and (ii) Ln 2233 Tuzla Region Water and Environmental Project. The two loans totalled $51 million. The Sarajevo project comprised rehabilitation and expansion of the water distribution networks and the construction of a wastewater treatment plant (This plant was damaged during the war and requires extensive repairs to be placed in operation). The Tuzla project increased production capacity and provided for a major interceptor to convey wastewater to the site of a proposed wastewater treatment plant. The wastewater treatment plant, also included in the project, was not built because of a shortage of counter-part funds. Components that were completed in each project were well executed. In 1990, BH while still a part of Yugoslavia, opened discussions with the Bank about possible financing of several regional water supply systems. These discussions were suspended with the breakup of Yugoslavia in 1991.
 Technical Annex Page 3 B. BANK RESPONSE AND STRATEGY Sector Recovery Program 9. The sector recovery program for BH is based on planning carried out by the Federation, the Republic of Srpska, the International Management Group (IMG) and the World Health Organization (WHO). The IMG was established in 1993 by the European Union to provide technical assistance to the Federation and the Republic of Srpska for the restoration of war damaged infrastructure. The Federation's planning is based mostly on requests for assistance received from municipalities and local sector operating organizations. IMG and the WHO have carried out a limited number of pre-feasibility studies for water supply rehabilitation projects in Federation municipalities and have carried out inventories of needs in the Republic of Srpska. The program is designed to be implemented in three years through three phased country-wide projects. The first project would comprise urgent works, the second project rehabilitation works, and the third project system upgrading works. 10. The objectives of the program are: (i) to meet the immediate needs of the affected population; (ii) to return water management facilities to pre-war conditions; (iii) to make selected improvements that are of high priority; and (iv) to help establish the institutions needed to sustain the sector over the long term. The cost of the program is estimated at $380 million (which works out at approximately $115 per capita for the population of 3.3 million in the BH). The implementation period is three years. The third project would comprise system upgrading works ($122 million) which would be introduced in areas where systems are operational but in serious need of upgrading either because their economic life is coming to an end or because outdated technology is causing unacceptably high operating costs or inadequate performance. In the water supply sector ($86 million), piped water supply would be extended to unserved populations, water production and treatment facilities would be expanded, water distribution networks would be reinforced and administrative buildings would be upgraded. For sanitation ($10 million), primary treatment plants would be constructed where health and environmental benefits are clearly identifiable. For solid waste ($8 million), the Project would extend the rehabilitation project actions in land fills and equipment to further locations. For flood control and drainage ($10 million) the level of protection of existing systems where the benefits exceed the cost by a wide margin, would be increased. For irrigation ($8 million) the project would continue the work started under the Rehabilitation Project. 14. In addition to the investments described above, it would be necessary to provide funds in all three projects for recurrent costs of the local operating organizations and to help establish and build up sector institutions at the level of the republic and the regions. This would support the new structure of the country emerging from the peace negotiations. Clearly significant amounts of equipment (vehicles, office equipment, computers, etc.) will be needed to support this investment effort and the future management and development of the sector. The estimated cost of these activities and needs over the three year period is $30 million. This amount would also permit studies in water management of key river basins to be conducted as well as some basic work on water strategy planning. Such studies have been identified by government engineers as sorely lacking and necessary to establish the coherence of the water management effort. The cost of these studies within the $30 million allowance is estimated to be $4 million. In addition an allocation of $23 million to cover the costs of project management, engineering and technical assistance has been included. Out of the $53 million, $10 million would be spent under the first project, $25 million under the second project and $17 million under the third project.
 Technical Annex Page 6 C. THE PROJECT Project Objectives 15. The deterioration of the water, sanitation and solid waste infrastructure as a result of the war has been described above. Full recovery to pre-war conditions will take time. However, there are some actions that can improve service quickly and remove risks to public health. Also, actions must be taken now to prepare for those works that will take more time to implement and to start making the institutional changes that will result in long term sustainability of the sector. These are the objectives of this Project. Project Description 16. To meet these objectives, the Project would comprise five parts. (i) the supply of equipment and materials; (ii) urgent works for the provision of water supply sanitation and solid waste services in municipalities; (iii) emergency sector planning; (iv) institutional strengthening through the provision of technical assistance, training and recurrent cost financing; and (v) the preparation rehabilitation and upgrading type projects for implementation under a second project. Each part of the Project is described in detail as follows: 17. Part A. Supply of Eguipment and Materials (US$ 15 million equivalent). During the war, much rolling stock and construction equipment used for maintenance and repair was either destroyed, stolen or stopped working for lack of spare parts. Also, pipes, fittings, repair materials and small tools maintained in reserve for emergency repairs were either destroyed or used up without replacement. Since the war's end, many utilities have identified urgent repair works that could be carried out with their own maintenance personnel if they had the materials. This component would be aimed at meeting all these needs. The needs of operating organizations serving about 40 municipalities would be met under this component. Equipment and materials under this component would only be provided to municipalities that have demonstrated that they have sufficient resources to use them without additional financial assistance. A list of the first 12 municipalities selected to be assisted under this part of the Project and their needs is in Appendix 2. 18. Part B. Urgent Works for the Provision of Water Supply, Sanitation and Solid Waste Services for Municipalities (US$47 million equivalent). Many of the water supply and sewerage systems in Bosnia suffered both direct damage from shelling or indirect damage from lack of maintenance. Also, shifts in population have resulted in increased demands being put on some systems while others have seen a decrease in demand. The situation in Sarajevo is typical of that found in many other smaller cities. Water service is intermittent with some areas of the city only receiving water for an hour or so every other day. Because of the low system pressures, the upper floors of some apartment buildings receive no water at all. Also, when consumers have water pressure, their is no incentive to conserve it because meters are either broken or not read. As a result of all these deficiencies, system losses exceed 50% of production. The sewage collection system also suffers from neglect. Back-ups into buildings and the flooding of streets with sewage are common occurrences. This component would comprise repair and rehabilitation type works (including goods, consultants' services and commercial services) aimed at reducing these problems in Sarajevo, Zenica, Tuzla, Travnik, Bihac and 15 other priority municipalities. Typical works to be undertaken in all the municipalities are as follows: * Rehabilitation of well field and pumping stations to restore capacity * Rehabilitation of booster pumping stations

A list of the municipalities from which the 20 municipalities comprising Part B of the Project would be selected is in Appendix 3. 20. Part C. Emergencv Development Plan for the Water Management Sector (US$0.6 million equivalent). The planning done to date for the reconstruction of the water management sector by IMG and the WHO is only partially complete. Also, these plans have been prepared in isolation so that it is difficult to determine priorities. The emergency development plan would inventory every water and sewerage and solid waste system serving the Federation's 70 municipalities, assess needs and recommend solutions to overcome existing problems. Alternative solutions would be evaluated. The final result would be a prioritized list of interventions integrated into an overall plan for all 70 municipaliLies. Emergency planning for Sarajevo and Mostar has already been completed; therefore, they are not included in the proposed study; however, their projects would be integrated into the final project priority list resulting from the plan. 21. Part D. Institutional Strengthening (US$2.0 million equivalent). This component would have two parts. The first part would comprise training. At the Federation level, the training would focus on strategic planning, sector organization and project management. An important aspect of the training would focus on private sector involvement for the provision of municipal water, sanitation and solid waste services, starting with solid waste collection. Training in the financial control of projects and bookkeeping for the financial staff would be an important part of the project management training. At the municipal level, the focus would be on project management, financial management, maintenance management, computer skills and the reduction of unaccounted-for water. Twinning arrangements with water and sewerage works organizations in donor countries would be used to the maximum extent possible. The second part of the Project would provide financing of incremental operating costs for VBH and the municipalities to implement and start up the Project. 22. Part E. Preparation of the Water, Sanitation and Solid Waste Rehabilitation Project (US$5.0 million equivalent). The scope of work would comprise final designs, procurement documentation and the contracting of works scheduled for implementation under the second project. The works would be identified in the Emergency Plan. Project Cost and Financing Plan 23. Proiect Cost. The State would be the Borrower and would onlend the proceeds of the Bank Credit to the Federation. The Federation, through VBH as its agent, would use the proceeds of the Bank Credit to provide credits to the benefitting municipalities under Part A, B and D of the Project. During negotiations, it was agreed that the onlending terms would be 30 years maturity at zero interest including 7 years grace. The credit agreements between the Federation and each municipality would provide for a percentage of the amounts received to be forgiven. The percentage would be determined as soon as the repayment conditions of all financing for the project is known. It would be calculated by dividing the amount of grant financing in the financing plan by the total cost of the Project. It is estimate that about 60% of each municipal credit could be forgiven. The cost of Parts C and E of the Project would be paid by the Federation. 26. Cost Recovery. Most water and sewerage works in the Federation have been unable to collect for their services during the conflict. It would be difficult to reinstate charges in the short term, and it is unlikely that any municipality would be able to contribute to the cost of the Project from any other source except in kind. However, there should be some commitment by the benefitting municipalities to obtain cost recovery in the future so that they can repay the credits. During negotiations, it was agreed that each benefitting municipality would submit an Action Plan for increasing the revenues for water, sanitation and solid waste collection services to a level that would permit recovery of operating costs in two years and all costs, including depreciation, in seven years. It was further agreed that the submission

Financial and Economic Justification 27. The Project is primarily focussed on rehabilitation work, which has in general economic rates of return in excess of 30 percent. These returns result from reduction in the large amounts of unaccounted for water (estimated to be greater than 50 percent) and the related declines in usage of electricity and chemicals. Moreover, the crucial rehabilitation effort at this juncture on severely deteriorated works will save millions of dollars in investments that, in the absence of the Project, would have to be made to totally or in large part replace systems for both water and wastewater. 28. To ensure that only the most economically viable projects are undertaken, assurances were obtained during negotiations that all municipal project components would be selected based on an assigned priority. Criteria for assigning priorities, which would be applied sequentially, are as follows: (i) Deficiency in water quantity; (ii) Deficiency in water quality which constitutes a severe threat to public health; (iii) Large number of beneficiaries; (iv) Deficiency in water supply, sanitation or solid waste disposal which constitutes a constraint to economic development; and (v) The proposed project includes cost-effective interconnection of systems. Environmental Aspects 29. The Project would have positive environmental impacts as a result of reduction in water losses, a safer water supply, improved sewage collection and proper disposal of solid waste. There is no resettlement involved. In addition, all work would be monitored during supervision to ensure that there is no degradation to the environment. In project components that include the extension or improvement of sewage collection systems, special care will be taken to mitigate the effects of concentrating sewage discharges so that surface water and ground water sources of public water supply are not endangered. The Project has no significant negative environmental impact and has been placed in environmental screening category "B". D. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION Project Organization 30. The responsible Government Ministry is the Ministry of Agriculture, Water Resources and Forestry (MAWRF). MAWRF would have general oversight for the Project and set policy. VBH would have overall responsibility for implementing the Project. Organizational changes and staffing of VBH would be approved by MAWRF. Regarding the Project, MAWRF would approve recipients of the financial assistance under Parts A, B and D of the Project and deal with any other related matters. The MAWRF would also be responsible for negotiating the conditions of other potential donors. Decisions about implementation of the Project would be left to VBH as the agent of the Federation. 31. A special Projects Development Department has been established in VBH with the responsibility of managing all reconstruction projects. The Projects Development Department Director would have overall charge of the Project. Reporting to the Director would be two division heads--one for engineering and one for research and development. The VBH Legislative Management Division would advise on

The Investments Department would be responsible for all procurement and the Finance and Administration Department would oversee the financial management of the Project. The VBH regional offices would be responsible for overseeing the implementation of the Project in their respective areas. For purposes of the Project, the head of each VBH regional office would report to the Project Development Department Director. VBH would be responsible for approving all equipment requests from the municipalities benefitting from Part A of the Project and passing these requests on to the EC project office in Sarajevo to procure and deliver. VBH would carry out the procurement for its own equipment under Part A of the Project and all works and consulting services under Part B of the Project. The municipalities would be responsible for supervising the contracts after they are signed. 32. As a result of the war, many managers and engineers have left VBH; and there is a shortage of qualified personnel required for the task of managing the reconstruction program so that VBH needs strengthening. To assist with the rebuilding and strengthening, VBH would hire five foreign advisors on a full-time basis and short-term experts on an as needed basis under Part D of the Project. An internationally experienced water operating company would be contracted to provide for the short-term experts. Most of the assistance would be for advice in the area of project design and procurement. 33. The Federation would like to encourage the development of the local construction and consulting industry by seeing as much of the engineering and construction work contracted to local firms. The local consulting firms are for the most part firms comprising individuals who used to work for the design institutes that did most of the engineering work in former Yugoslavia. Individuals and small firms from Croatia and Slovenia are also expected to be competitive and win contracts for some of the engineering consulting assignments. Local contractors and contractors from Croatia and Slovenia would have good prospects of winning a large percentage of the works contracts because of their local knowledge and the fact that most of the bid packages would be too small to interest foreign contractors. The local contractors would comprise recently formed firms founded by local entrepreneurs who use to work for the large construction institutes that did most of the work in former Yugoslavia. Many of these new groups are supported technically and financially by foreign construction companies. 34. A project organization chart for the Project is in Appendix 4. Project Implementation 35. The equipment and materials to be supplied to the municipalities selected under Part A of the Project, Supply of Equipment and Materials, would be procured by the VBH Procurement Division. To benefit from this part of the Project, the municipalities would be required to make a formal request to VBH (this has been done), to sign a credit agreement with the Federation and to confirm receipt of the goods when they arrive. 36. The municipalities selected for assistance under Part B, Urgent Works for Municipalities, would follow the same procedures as in Part A. VBH would contract and provide general oversight of the works, and the municipalities manage implementation of the contracts. Small works with an aggregate value of about US$2.0 million would be carried out with the municipality's own staff and day laborers under force account. However, most work would be performed under contract. The VBH regional offices would verify the works and approve payments. The funds would be disbursed from the VBH main office in Sarajevo. Contractors under the supervision of the municipality komunalcos would implement the larger works. The VBH Sarajevo office would contract the large works. The regional offices would contract the small works. For force account work, agreements specifying the scope of work and the terms for reimbursement would be entered into between VBH and the executing municipality.

The VBH regional office in consultation with the municipality would define the scope of the project. The VBH regional office would then contract a consultant (a local consultant if qualified) to prepare designs and bidding documents under their direction but in consultation with the municipality. For IS, NS and DC, the limits and procedures would be as follows: (a) IS/NS. International Shopping (IS) would be used for procuring equipment and materials estimated to cost between US$200,000 and US$2.0 million per contract. Awards would be based on comparison of price quotations obtained from at least three suppliers in two countries. A sample document, including contract conditions, has been prepared by the Bank and would be used for IS contracts. National Shopping (NS) would be used for goods available within BH, such as office furniture and supplies, up to an estimated cost of US$ 200,000 per contract with at least three quotations from national suppliers. The aggregate amount of Bank-financed goods using IS would not exceed US$0.5 million. The aggregate amount of Bank-financed goods bid using NS would not exceed US$0.1 million. (b) DC. Direct Contracting (DC) would be used for proprietary items, for reasons of compatibility or standardization, as well as for reasons of timing. No DC is foreseen for those goods
 Technical Annex Page 14 financed by the Bank. Any DC during project implementation would require prior Bank approval. Existing contracts would not be extended. At the time of project appraisal, no DC was anticipated. 41. Contracted Works. For works carried out under contract, the following procedures would be followed: (a) ICB. ICB would apply for works contracts estimated to cost more than $5.0 million each. Regarding advertising procedures, a General Procurement Notice (GPN) would be published in the "Development Business" and the local press in March 1996 (see Appendix 6). The notice would include information about the nature of goods and services to be procured and invite interested and eligible contractors to send their expressions of interest to VBH. A specific advertisement for prequalification and individual contracts would appear in the local press. Copies of the advertisement would be sent to contractors who respond to the GPN. The Bank's Standard Bidding Document for Works would be used. Any modification would be approved by the Bank prior to the documents being issued. Bid and payment currency would be limited to one currency widely used in international trade. The aggregate amount of Bank-financed works bid using ICB would not exceed US$10.3 million. (b) NCB. Because foreign contractors are unlikely to be interested in small works that would be widely dispersed, National Competitive Bidding (NCB) would be used for works contracts between US$1.0 and US$5.0 million per contract. Interested foreign contractors would be allowed to tender for NCB contracts. Contractors for NCB would be prequalified. The procedure would differ from the Bank's normal procedure in that an open registry of prequalified contractors would be kept and based on information submitted contractors would be prequalified by category of works and contract price. A prequalification notice would be put in the local press at least once during project implementation but could be repeated if more firms are needed. The prequalification document would be approved by the Bank. The ECA Region's sample document for works using NCB dated September 1995 would be used for all tenders. The currency of the bid and contract would be Deutsche Marks. Announcements of tenders would be sent only to contractors on the registry that meet the minimum requirements of the tender. The aggregate amount of Bank-financed works bid using NCB would not exceed US$2.5 million. (c) SWP. Small Works Procurement (SWP) would be used for works contracts estimated to cost less than US$1.0 million per contract. Contracts would be lump sum, fixed price contracts awarded on the basis of quotations obtained from three qualified contractors in response to a written invitation. The invitation would include a detailed description of the works, the basic specifications, the required completion period, a basic form of agreement and drawings when relevant. The award would be made to the contractor who offers the lowest price. The aggregate amount of Bank-financed Works bid using SNCB would not exceed US$1.6 million. 42. Force Account Works (FA). For the installation of equipment and minor repair work within the capability of the staff of municipal water, sanitation and solid waste organizations and valued at less than $150,000, FA would be allowed. To qualify, organizations would need to demonstrate that they have the equipment, capacity and experience to undertake the work. The total value of FA permitted any one municipality would be limited to US$0.5 million. FA work would be paid on the basis of standard unit prices developed from the bids received for similar work carried out by private contractors. The
 Technical Annex Page 15 aggregate amount of Bank-financed works bid using FA would not exceed $2.0 million. 43. Recurrent Costs, Tuition and Travel. VBH and other municipalities that qualify for incremental operating costs would be reimbursed monthly based on an approved program and budget. Tuition and travel would be reimbursed based on actual expenditures. The aggregate amount of Bank-financed recurrent costs, tuition and travel would not exceed US$1.3 million. 44. Consultants and Commercial Services. Consultant and commercial services would be procured in accordance with Bank guidelines which shall include both competition, sole sourcing and the selection of individual consultants. The sole sourcing would be justified in each case. Such justifications may be the timing constraint, continuity, unique expertise, and lack of candidates given the situation in BH. Follow-up assignments would be permissible to the extent that they are indicated in the initial Terms of Reference for the assignments. The aggregate value of Bank-financed consulting and commercial services is estimated at US$1.7 million of which US$1.0 million would be through shortlisting of firms and US$0.7 million would be for individual consultants, representing assignments of specialized and short term nature. 45. Procurement Implementation Capacitv. At present, VBH lacks the capacity to undertake the procurement under the project without outside assistance. Local consultants under the direction of VBH's Project Development Department, would carry out all the procurement for works under the Project. To instruct its own staff and the local consultants, VBH will seek the assistance of the procurement advisors engaged for the Emergency Recovery Project (approved by the Board on February 29, 1996). Because most of the goods would be procured by the contractors for the works, procurement agents (PA) for most of the goods to be procured under the project would not be required. In cases where it is necessary to procure goods separately, VBH would seek the assistance of the procurement unit of the Emergency Recovery Project or employ an individual procurement consultants on a contract by contract basis. 46. Prior and Post Bank Review of Procurement Documents. Bank Standard Bidding Documents would be used for ICB procurement packages for works. The Bank Standard Prequalification Document would be used to prequalify works contractors for ICB. A simplified prequalification document prepared by VBH would be used to prequalify works contractors for NCB. Sample bidding documents prepared by the Bank would be used for NCB and IS. These documents would be used also for procurement under the Project. All ICB contracts for works, the first three contracts for NCB and IS, all contracts for DC and agreements for works to be carried by FA would be subject to the Bank's prior review as stated in the Procurement Guidelines. Also, prequalification documents for both ICB and NCB would be reviewed prior to being issued, and the results of all prequalification results would be subject to prior review. For consultants' contracts, the Bank's standard form for consultants' contracts would be used. Terms of reference for all consultant contracts with firms above US$100,000, contracts with individuals above US$50,000 and sole source contracts, if any, would be subject to the Bank's prior review. Post reviews of procurement actions would be carried out on a quarterly basis by Bank supervision missions. 47. Local Control of Procurement. In order to ensure transparency in procurement arrangements for the Project, especially because there would be a large number of small civil works contracts, likely to be financed by local firms, during negotiations agreement was reached with the Borrower that they would cause the Federation to establish a water management sector Procurement Review Committee. The Committee would be responsible for ensuring compliance with Bank and donor procurement procedures and approving all contract awards. Membership of the Committee would comprise the Director of VBH who would serve as secretary, an Assistant Minister of Agriculture, Water Resources and Forestry who would serve as chairman and three other members, one of which would be from a municipality participating the Project. IMG would advise the Committee on technical and

The authorized allocation of the Special Account would be limited to US$ 2.0 million, representing about four months (average) disbursement of the Bank's share of estimated expenditures expected to be paid from the Special Account. Disbursements would be made against Statements of Expenditures (SOEs) for the following types of expenditures: (i) expenditures for goods under contracts not exceeding US$2,000,000 equivalent; (ii) expenditures for works under contracts not exceeding US$1,000,000 equivalent; (iii) expenditures for employment of consulting firms under contracts not exceeding US$100,000 equivalent; (iv) expenditures for commercial services under contracts not exceeding US$100,000 equivalent;

Disbursements for contracts exceeding the above limits would be made against presentation to the Bank of full contract documentation. 51. Credit Closing Date. The Credit closing date would be June 30, 1999. Accounts, Auditing and Reporting 52. Accounts. During negotianions, agreement was reached on the following arrangments for accounting, auditing and reporting. Separate and auditable accounts would be established by VBH for the Project. These accounts would include: (i) a record of all commitments and expenditures; (ii) a record of withdrawals from all funding sources including the Bank Credit (Trust Fund); (iii) copies of all disbursement requests and underlying documentation; and (iv) a record of transactions on the Special Account and the copies of the bank statements on this account. Technical assistance has been included under the Project to establish proper accounts and financial controlling procedures. 53. Audits. The project accounts would be audited annually by independent auditors and under terms of reference acceptable to the Bank. Separate audit statements would be prepared for the Special Account and for Statement of Expenditures. All audit reports would be made available to the Bank at the latest six months after the end of the fiscal year. Project accounts would be maintained for one year after the closing date. 54. Reporting. VHB would prepare and furnish to the Bank a quarterly progress report showing the status of implementation of the Project as well as a financial report in a format acceptable to the Bank. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Water, Sanitation and Solid Waste Urgent Works Project are to: (i) restore water, sanitation and solid waste services to the population depending on pipe water supply and water borne sewerage systems to a level that would mitigate public health risk in priority areas; (ii) develop a long term sector strategy and the details of an emergency project consistent with the strategy; (iii) rebuild and strengthen sector institutions so that the improvements will be sustainable; and (iv) prepare final designs and bidding documents for the rehabilitation project. The project consists of five parts: (a) the supply of equipment and materials, including pipe, fittings, spare parts and rolling stock for water, sewerage and solid waste disposal operating organizations to meet urgent requirements for systems operations; (b) urgent works for the provision of water supply, sanitation and solid waste services for municipalities, including rehabilitation and repair of water sources and distribution networks; (c) emergency development plan for the water management sector; (d) institutional strengthening, focusing on strategic planning and sector organization, project, financial and maintenance management, computer skills and reduction of unaccounted-for water; and (e) preparation of the water, sanitation and solid waste rehabilitation project.
